titleStmt.title: [in Armory Ward C]
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: No image of verso currently available.

This manuscript was likely composed in September 1863. Union soldier Manville Winterstein was injured in the battle of Culpeper Court House in Culpeper, Virginia on September 13, 1863, and, on September 14, 1863, he was hospitalized in Armory Square in Washington, D.C. His name and a description of his injuries also appear in Whitman's "September & October 1863."
The following are responsible for particular readings or for changes to this file, as noted: Elizabeth Lorang Ashley Lawson Tim Jackson

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: A Series of Washington Hospital Notes. Written at the bedsides of wounded soldiers. Washington, 1863–1865.
bibl.orgName: The Oscar Lion Papers, 1914–1955, New York Public Library, New York, N.Y.
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

body.p: A noble sized young fellow Manville WintersteinM. W.of co K 6th Ohio, gun shot wound lft shoulder,—I cut up some peaches, powder them with sugar, for his supper—he relishes them much—for him too I write he has suffered, but lies easy now— what a splendid frame neck, frame, & clean complexion.
